data.title: HLSL losing vertex elements?

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
I posted this to the community forums after staring at it for several days... I think I've ruled out the possibility of it being something foolish on my end.

http://community.monogame.net/t/hlsl-losing-vertex-elements/7724/

In summary, one call to DrawUserIndexedPrimitives seems to be affecting another several calls later, despite setting a different render target and clearing the graphics device several times in between, etc. For what it's worth, they're both acting upon different techniques in the same effect, although it's not EffectPass.Apply that's causing the issue. Oddly, the vertex shader of the later call in question seems to have all of its vertex elements - except for Position - set to zero, despite the incoming vertex data.

I tried downloading the Monogame source to debug locally, but I had issues compiling it, probably related to reference/external dependencies.

data.title: "We don't support multidimensional arrays!"
More rendertarget fixes
data.body:
My last PR had a typo in it where DepthStencilState.StencilEnable was used instead of RasterizerState.ScissorTestEnable to determine if the scissor test is currently enabled.

This also fixes an issue where framebuffers used for the resolve operation are never properly removed  when deleting the corresponding multisampled rendertarget. This becomes a critical issue if you create and delete a lot of RT during the lifetime of your application (not the most common use case though).

data.title: [Pipeline Tool] PropertyGridTable Improvements
data.body:
Stuff done:
- text editing now has a textbox inside property grid
- numbers are now editable and have a textbox inside property grid (fixes #4905)
- disabled height overriding of cellcombo for Gtk, it got cut off on some themes

PS. I snuck in a line of change to `Global.Linux.cs` since I noticed a bug with it while doing this PR

data.title: Pipeline Tool: rotation/scale of object cannot be modifed
data.body:
FBX object (at least) rotation & scale cannot be modified using Pipeline tool UI from dev branch.

double click on property didn't pop-up a way to edit value like ColorKeyColor for instance.

(editing content.mgcb, or whatever its name is, is the only way to do it for now)

data.title: MojoShader returns garbage sampler information
Unit Tests for MaterialProcessor

I have written some unit tests for the MaterialProcessor (#4333). 

I need to figure out how to setup material content with OpaqueData and Textures to test some more of the process method.

data.title: Flickering when using the DesktopGL Library w/windows 10.
data.body: Getting a weird constant flicker with basic spritebatch stuff when using the DesktopGL backend. Issue ceases when using the DirectX backend.

data.title: Issue in CreatePixelShader
Input seriously lagging in UWP
data.body:
Keyboard and mouse input is seriously lagging in UWP games.
When you use `Keyboard.GetState().IsKeyDown( ... )` you will find out that it returns true usually even several Updates after the key is released.
Similar lag occurs for mouse state.

This is quite serious as it renders the framework unusable - or rather the games hardly playable.

Edit: I have confirmed this behavior with another developer, so it is not just an issue on my side.

data.title: Normal definition dropped when converting to GLSL
data.body:
For some reason, when translating my shader code to GLSL, the definition of the normal passed from the vertex to the fragment shader is lost. I tested compiling it in DirectX and it works properly there; the problem is therefore most likely in MojoShader.  (So, I don't know how much you can do about it...)

Code and detailed description is already [here](http://community.monogame.net/t/shader-code-dropping-normal-when-translating-to-glsl-monogame-bug/7688).

data.title: Remove/Change MonoKickstart
data.body:
We currently have a submodule for MonoKickstart here:

 https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/tree/develop/ThirdParty/Kickstart

It points to this repo...

https://github.com/OutOfOrder/MonoKickstart/tree/5e03d0127e514dcf8a63ae9ebd385cd392dcde52

... and for some reason not our fork...

https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoKickstart

What do we need to do here?  Do we update the submodule?  Do we remove it?

data.title: Implement EffectMaterialWriter
data.body: This implements EffectMaterialWriter and does some other little fixes so we can [render a model with a custom effect](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/shawnhar/2006/12/07/rendering-a-model-with-a-custom-effect/). Fixes #4884.

data.title: EffectParameter.SetValue(string) not implemented
data.body: I just noticed [XNA's SetValue(string)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb198904.aspx) for an EffectParameter is not implemented in MonoGame. I don't know why you would want to pass data to a shader as a string, and it sure doesn't seem useful, but I came across it and saw it was implemented in XNA so here we are :)

data.title: Move LZX decompress code from ContentManager into LzxDecoderStream
data.body:
Added LzxDecoderStream similar to Lz4DecoderStream and make ContentManager a bit cleanner.
Related to https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/4522

data.title: How get keyframes ofAnimations?
data.body:
I debugged the open asset importer ( I imported an FBX file) and could see that animations are indeed read and stored in the imported object. However, the ModelProcesser seem not to handle these animations and the ModelContent has no attribute for AnimationContent, only got bones and meshes. 
Have I missed something here? Is there Another way getting key frames from animations?

data.title: Implemented tvOS controller support for sticks and triggers.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Implemented tvOS controller support for left analog stick, right analog stick, left shoulder button, right shoulder button, left trigger, right trigger.

Addresses https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4889

data.title: GamePad does not return some properties for steelseries controller

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
I have tested this on an Apple TV with a steelseries controller. The following properties do not work. The steelseries controller does have appropriate hardware to return these values, but they return 0 or false despite the hardware being pressed:
- Buttons.LeftShoulder
- Buttons.RightShoulder
- ThumbSticks.Left
- Thumbsticks.Right
- Triggers.Left
- Triggers.right

The following properties are reporting values as expected:
- Buttons.A
- Buttons.B
- Buttons.X
- Buttons.Y
- DPad.Down
- DPad.Left
- DPad.Right
- DPad.Up

data.body:

@dellis1972 @mrhelmut This fixes the problem of running 32 bit SDL and exe on 64 bit host :)

data.title: Monogame installer screws Visual Studios' UWP deployment
data.body:
Hi just installed Monogame 3.6 installer and I noticed my VS 2015 Update 2 gets stuck when deploying UWP apps, even those not being a Monogame project.

To make sure this issue is coming from Monogame, I installed a clean windows 10 and vs 2015 and the same problem happened.

Previously I had MG 3.5 official release with no problem.

data.title: [Pipeline Tool] Use Wpf backend for Windows
data.body:
NEEDS: https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame.Dependencies/pull/86

Originally I was doing this for #4872 but turns out regardless of that issue, Wpf backend is better then the WinForms one. 

Advantages that I like:
- color selection has alpha
- treeview icons appear full color

Temporary multiselect won't work, this will be fixed with #4872 or native Wpf implementation.

Screenshot:
![wpf](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6773302/15613258/f5c2cff2-2432-11e6-9ce5-790acf82c207.png)

data.title: ExternalReference issue when loading fbx
data.body:
To test #4875 I wanted to try the [InstancedModel Sample](http://xbox.create.msdn.com/en-US/education/catalog/sample/mesh_instancing), but I ran into some issues importing a .fbx model. 
- First there was a problem in the ContentWriter about writing a non-.xnb file. This was caused by [EffectMaterialContent.Effect](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/Graphics/EffectMaterialContent.cs#L14) being serialized, since it's an external reference to a non-xnb file. This was an easy fix, I solved it by adding [ContentSerializerIgnore] above it. 
- Second, there was an error thrown [here](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/Serialization/Compiler/ContentWriter.cs#L296) because the filename of the reference did not begin with the root directory, which was caused by [NormalizeOS](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/ExternalReference.cs#L63) in ExternalReference, since it changed directory separators in the ExternalReference so the strings didn't match up. Also an easy fix! I Changed that so it does a regular normalize rather than NormalizeOS (do the separators really matter as long as they're consistent? NormalizeOS is now not used anymore).
- After that it built fine! However when loading the model it can't find the content reader for ExternalReference<CompiledEffectContent>. This is the hard one :p After digging through the code a bit, I think it should resolve to a regular ExternalReferenceReader, so it can load the file that's referenced (the reader for the effect itself is loaded, so that would work), but I got a bit confused when I saw the content readers include
  
  ```
  {[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.NamedValueDictionary`1[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.ExternalReference`1[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.TextureContent]] 
  ```
  
  It seems weird to have a reader for a specific generic type like that, I thought a generic reader should read its content and delegate to the reader that can handle it. In this case I would expect a NamedValueDictionaryReader, an ExternalReferenceReader and a TextureContentReader to handle a type like this, each delegating internally to the next. So my question is if I should make the writer when asked for the runtime reader write out the full name of the type (e.g. ExternalReferenceReader`1[[sometype]]) or make [ContentTypeReaderManager.GetTypeReader](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Content/ContentTypeReaderManager.cs#L59) a bit smarter to use a reader for the outer type when it encounters generics. I really wouldn't go for the first option, but I don't know if the second one is applicable in general (for all generic types). I think we could make it work though, and it would be **a lot** neater.

data.title: [Don't merge] WIP replace OpenTK
data.body:
This is basically #4874 + https://github.com/mrhelmut/MonoGame/tree/SDLDep which includes installer and template updates.

This PR is meant to check if everything is fine and that the artifacts build and pass the tests. Hope you don't mind.

The legit PR is #4874.

data.title: Fix GetBufferData for Index- and VertexBuffer on OpenGL
data.body: Binding was wrong in IndexBuffer and both did not take startIndex and elementCount into account in all cases.

data.title: [Pipeline Tool] Linux Headerbar :)
data.body: With #4786 this was temporarily disabled since the PR was big enough.

data.title: List only the displaymodes for the current display.
data.body:
In the current implementation of the SDL back end we list ALL
the displaymodes for evey display. I need to check with XNA but
it seems we should only list the modes for the current display. Otherwise
you might end up trying to set a mode which isn't supported.

Anyone with XNA able to confirm the DisplayMode list is for the "current" display only.
